# Draft:Composable Software

----
Composable software is an approach to software engineering in which applications are built from independent, reusable components such as services, application programming interfaces (APIs), modules, or Packaged Business Capabilities (PBCs). The paradigm emphasizes modularity, interoperability, and flexibility, allowing organizations to adapt systems incrementally in response to changing requirements. It has been applied in domains including enterprise systems, e-commerce, infrastructure, and data management, and is regarded as a continuation of earlier approaches such as component-based software engineering, service-oriented architecture, and microservices.
History and background
Composable software builds on earlier architectural approaches such as component-based software engineering (CBSE), service-oriented architecture (SOA), and microservices. As organizations encountered limitations in monolithic architectures—including slow release cycles and low adaptability—interest increased in more modular alternatives. Developments in cloud computing, containerization, and API-driven systems have further accelerated adoption.
Principles
Key principles associated with composable software include:
* Modularity: Components are self-contained and focused on specific functions.
* Autonomy: Components can be developed, deployed, and modified independently.
* Interoperability: Components interact through standard APIs or event-driven mechanisms.
* Discoverability and reusability: Components are documented and reused across different systems.
* Loose coupling: Dependencies are minimized so changes in one component have limited impact.
Applications
Composable software has been applied in several domains:
* Enterprise systems: Migration from monolithic systems to modular, API-driven architectures.
* E-commerce: Composable commerce allows integration of modular services such as payments, recommendations, and inventory management.
* Infrastructure: Composable infrastructure supports dynamic allocation of compute, storage, and network resources.
* Data management: Modular data stacks support interoperability and extensibility.
Benefits
Documented benefits include:
* Faster time-to-market through reuse of components.
* Greater adaptability to business or technological changes.
* Reduced risk during upgrades, since modules can be replaced incrementally.
* Efficiency through reuse of standardized components.
Challenges
Challenges associated with composable software include:
* Complexity in integration and dependency management.
* Governance issues such as versioning, documentation, and security.
* Organizational resistance or skills gaps in adopting modular architectures.
* Costs and risks associated with migrating from legacy monolithic systems.
Recent research
Academic work has expanded on the concept:
* Ivas et al. (2024) describe industry use cases of composable enterprise adoption, emphasizing incremental implementation.
* Pedreira et al. (2023) proposed the Composable Data Management System Manifesto, outlining modularity as a principle for next-generation data systems.
